pullRequest.body:
This PR defines `RefinedDiscrTree`, which is an improved version of `DiscrTree` with many new features, such as
- indexing lambda terms, dependent forall terms, and bound variables.
- giving a score to matches, in order to sort them
- indexing star patterns so that `a+b` and `a+a` are indexed differently
- distributing lambdas over +, *, etc. so that `fun x => f x + g x` and `f + g` are indexed the same
- indexing `id` and `fun x => x` as the same
- taking into account eta reductions, so that `exp` can still be matched with the library pattern `fun x => exp (f x)`.

Additionally, `RefinedDiscrTree` is a lazy data structure, meaning that it can be used without a cache, just like `LazyDiscrTree`.

This is part of the bigger #11768, which uses this discrimination tree for a library rewriting tactic.

This replaces an older version of `RefinedDiscrTree`.

---

(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Any other comments you want to keep out of the PR commit should go
below the `---`, and placed outside this HTML comment, or else they
will be invisible to reviewers.

- [ ] depends on: #xyz [optional extra text]
-->

nodes.body: awaiting-review

> I also wonder if `isNumeral` and `reduce` are useful outside of this file

These functions are defined in the same exact way in Lean's `DiscrTree`. So If they were useful anywhere else, they should be used from there.

It looks like [Mathlib.Tactic.FunProp.RefinedDiscrTree](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/blob/master/Mathlib/Tactic/FunProp/RefinedDiscrTree.lean) (authored by yourself) is already in mathlib and almost identical to the main file added here.

Could you please update this PR so that it either updates the existing file, or replaces the usage of that in favour of your new file? Or is there a reason for this being duplicated?

As mentioned on [Zulip](https://leanprover.zulipchat.com/#narrow/stream/287929-mathlib4/topic/Point.26Click.20library.20rewrite.20tactic/near/447023540), `RefinedDiscrTree` should be made lazy, so that it doesn't require cache.

As for [Mathlib.Tactic.FunProp.RefinedDiscrTree](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/blob/master/Mathlib/Tactic/FunProp/RefinedDiscrTree.lean), it would probably be good to update it to the current most recent version of `RefinedDiscrTree`, but eventually it should switch to the lazy variant when I make it.

```

```
* The `relative` value is the weighted *sum* of the differences with weight given by the *inverse* of the current value of the statistic.
* The `absolute` value is the `relative` value divided by the total sum of the inverses of the current values (i.e. the weighted *average* of the differences).
</details>

I have rewritten the `RefinedDiscrTree` implementation, based on `LazyDiscrTree`. It is now a lazy data structure, meaning that it can be used for my library rewrite tactic without any pre built cache. I've also removed the old `RefinedDiscrTree` implementation from `fun_prop`, and replaced it with the new implementation (cc @lecopivo).

For plugging the lazy discrimination tree into `fun_prop`, the environment now contains the lazy discrimination tree instead of a strict one, which is good because it means we can avoid inserting lemmas with very long key sequences when we don't need them. However I wasn't sure how to replace the `RefinedDiscrTree` in the environment with an updated one (with some more nodes evaluated). So what I did instead is to store the progress of evaluating the lazy tree in the state of a single `fun_prop` call, and then throw this progress away at the end.

Another thing is that the data structure is not persistent: the array of all nodes needs to be copied from the environment for every `fun_prop` call

Both of these aren't a performance problem though, because evaluating the tree is quite fast, and the array of nodes in an un-evaluated tree is pretty short in the case of `fun_prop`.

Thanks for updating this! I might only be able to look at it early next week.

I removed the "WIP" label as this prevents reviwers from seeing the PR on the queue
Thanks for the review, but I'll probably only have time to work on it after next week.

The comments are about RefinedDiscrTree.Pi, which is the code that allows `fun x => f x + g x` and `f + g` to be indexed the same. However, this is problematic because these expressions aren't definitionally equal in the reducible transparency. For example in `simp` this would be useless.

I asked Tomas Skrivan, and he said that he doesn't need/use this feature in `fun_prop`.

So, I'll delete this part of the code. Also because the implementation is a bit awkward. If we ever need it, it can be added then.

Overall looks good. I would definitely want a second pair of eyes, as I haven't reviewed this style of code in a while.
I also wonder if `isNumeral` and `reduce` are useful outside of this file, but I'm not familiar enough with Mathlib's metaprogramming files to comment.

Overall looks good. I would definitely want a second pair of eyes, as I haven't reviewed this style of code in a while.
I also wonder if `isNumeral` and `reduce` are useful outside of this file, but I'm not familiar enough with Mathlib's metaprogramming files to comment.

```suggestion
    - When trying to find `Continuous.add` with the expression `Continuous fun x => 1 + x`,
      this is possible, because we first revert the eta-reduction that happens by default,
      and then distribute the lambda. Thus this is indexed as `Continuous (1 + id)`,
      which matches with `Continuous (f + g)` from `Continuous.add`.
```

```suggestion
```

```suggestion

```
Should this also include `HSMul.hSMul`, `HVAdd.hVAdd` and `HPow.hPow`?

I think so. In those we have the rules `fun i => s • x i` = `s • x` and `fun i => x i ^ b` = `x ^ b`. I think I'll move this part of the code to a separate file (the part for normalizing pi instances). In the long run when `RefinedDiscrTree` will move to std/Boost, this bit of code needs to stay in Mathlib because the pi instances are defined here. Then there should be a way to dynamically extend the reduction function. Then this code could go into `Mathlib.Algebra.Group.Pi.basic`, do it would run this if and only if the pi instances are imported.

I have reimplemented this code now, adding support for HSMul, HVAdd and HPow. In the process I also discovered a bug in an edge case. I have now added a test file to see that it is indeed doing what it should. There is now the function `reducePi` which does this normalization returning the result as an `Expr`, so that it can also be used somewhere else if that is useful.

```suggestion
Warning: to account for η-reduction, an entry may need to be added at multiple indexes,
```

```suggestion
Warning: to account for η-reduction, an entry may need to be added at multiple indexes,
```
The correct capitalization is either `vlhs` or `vLHS` (and similarly for `vRhs`).

```suggestion

/-- Return the possible `Trie α` that match with anything.
```
Folding with an `Alternative` seems like it should be abstracted, but I guess lean doesn't have `Foldable` types?
Ok. I see that `List` has `firstM`. This is essentially `lastM` but for `Array`?

I would also prefer if this fold with an alternative could be abstracted. I wasn't aware of `List.firstM`. That is essentially what I would need here, but for `Array`. Having the `Foldable` type class in Lean would solve this :)

```suggestion
```
`go` needs to have a docstring because otherwise the linter will complain 😞

```suggestion
    return lambdas.foldl (fun d _ => d.lam) e
```
Don't like the use of `·` with an anonymous `fun`.
Can you explain in the PR description what happened here? Did you split the file? Rewrite it from scratch? Move it with just enough modifications that git can no longer track it?

I think the diff might be easier to process if you make an initial PR that just moves `Tactic.FunProp.RefinedDiscrTree` to `Lean.Meta.RefinedDiscrTree`, without any other modifications.

That will at least cause github to show in this PR a diff in the long docstring, rather than showing it entirely added then deleted.
I split the one file into multiple files, and the files changed quite a lot in the process of making the disctimination tree lazy, so I think there won't be much of a meaningful diff.
I split out the move, and have resolved the superficial conflicts

I've now created #20381 to contain the split, without any refactoring. I'll resolve the merge conflicts by overwriting them with the contents of the current PR, so the final code will be unchanged; but hopefully this will cut the diff by 30%.
It seems there is still a merge conflict left over. How can I get rid of it?
Can you use ``` `` ``` to make this an error if the names change?
I did that oroginally, but it requires to import more, and then it complains about an unnecessary import
The unnecessary import can be silenced by running `lake exe shake --update`. Unless the import is particularly expensive (which CI will tell you), I think robustness matters more.
Is this cheaper than doing an `isDefEq` check against the canonical instances, as would happen with `~q()` matching? It certainly seems more fragile this way.
It is cheaper indeed, but this code won't run too many times, so it's probably fine to use isDefEq instead.

What's going on here is checking whether the expression is of the form `fun a b x => a x + b x` and if so, returning the `Add` instance. To do this with `isDefEq` would mean creating a term with a bunch of fresh metavariables, and if it unifies, extracting the value of the instance metaviable. I feel like this would be more cumbersome.

Moreover, I want to check against the form `fun a b x => a x + b x`, not the canonical Pi instance, because there can also be other instances that reduce to `fun a b x => a x + b x`, and I also want to treat these as Pi instances.

Ah sorry, I misread your implementation and thought you were checking against the canonical Pi instance. I now see that the names are references to the non-heterogenous instances!

A defeq check against the pi instance would work in the way you want, but indeed is more complex without benefit.

style nit:
```suggestion
  if constInfo.isUnsafe then return tree
  if LazyDiscrTree.blacklistInsertion env name then return tree
```

This code is performance critical since it gets run on most constants in the environment (when building the tree the first time). And the code doen't get compiled (instead it is run by the interpreter). When writing `if .. then return ..`, the compiler creates a separate function for the (implicit) else branch of the if statement, which is less efficient than a basic if-else.
Could you add a comment in the code to this effect?

optional: I find these easier to read as
```suggestion
          if let .some idx := stars[id]? then
            addLazyEntryToTrie idx entry
          else
            stars := stars.insert id (← newTrie entry)
```
Well, fiddling with the git history revealed something (very minor); you've discarded the change to summation syntax here, which probably you should revert.
Yes, you're right
This should use `WithLp.Equiv` to do the casting, not `show`.
I guess to make this less of a monster you could add an `def toPiLp := \u=(WithLp.equiv 1 (Unit → ℝ)).symm` on the line before
`Option (List (Array (Option Expr) × List FVarId` appears 4 times in this file; can you perhaps replace it with a `structure` so that you can document what the pieces mean?

I think its likely we will want `inf` and `sup` here too (and to a lesser extent, all the other lattice operators). Can you either add an extension mechanism for adding more entries here (and use it to register the existing ones), or a TODO comment about doing so?
Can these be merged by letting the caller pass in the argument positions / instance names?

I have rewritten the `RefinedDiscrTree` implementation, based on `LazyDiscrTree`. It is now a lazy data structure, meaning that it can be used for my library rewrite tactic without any pre built cache. I've also removed the old `RefinedDiscrTree` implementation from `fun_prop`, and replaced it with the new implementation (cc @lecopivo).

For plugging the lazy discrimination tree into `fun_prop`, the environment now contains the lazy discrimination tree instead of a strict one, which is good because it means we can avoid inserting lemmas with very long key sequences when we don't need them. However I wasn't sure how to replace the `RefinedDiscrTree` in the environment with an updated one (with some more nodes evaluated). So what I did instead is to store the progress of evaluating the lazy tree in the state of a single `fun_prop` call, and then throw this progress away at the end.

Another thing is that the data structure is not persistent: the array of all nodes needs to be copied from the environment for every `fun_prop` call

Both of these aren't a performance problem though, because evaluating the tree is quite fast, and the array of nodes in an un-evaluated tree is pretty short in the case of `fun_prop`.

The comments are about RefinedDiscrTree.Pi, which is the code that allows `fun x => f x + g x` and `f + g` to be indexed the same. However, this is problematic because these expressions aren't definitionally equal in the reducible transparency. For example in `simp` this would be useless.

I asked Tomas Skrivan, and he said that he doesn't need/use this feature in `fun_prop`.

So, I'll delete this part of the code. Also because the implementation is a bit awkward. If we ever need it, it can be added then.
